comment.author: 33898753@N00
comment._content: Can this really be 1900? Surely the Queen Victoria Building replaced the buildings on the left and was completed in 1898?

comment.author: 35699605@N00
comment._content: Sensational! That's very, very beautiful! I hope Flickr let you post older pictures! Congratulations for this wonderful collection!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The Centennial Hall (1888) is not yet built in this photo.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Johnson, William, Sir, (1862-1932). [Queen Victoria Markets, Sydney] [ca. 1900] - nla.gov.au/nla.pic-an2962616

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Good find! Even the horses and carts are in both. Another for the Equivalents (Old Sydney) gallery.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Yes, and it goes a long way towards proving that Sir William Elliot Johnson was not averse to copying from old photos.  Not that there is anything wrong with that!

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] But there might be something wrong with copying a fellow artist! Old George St markets (1889) by W. B. Spong The resemblance is uncanny - maybe Johnson and Spong were friends working side by side?

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Some more views of the old markets and Town Hall: - Looking south down York Street at old markets, central police court and Town Hall, Sydney (with Merlin's photographic cart, right ?) (1870-1875) - Looking south along York Street showing the Old Markets, Central Police Court, the Town Hall and W.A. Friend & Co., 185 York Street, (and other shops), Sydney (1870-1875) - York Street (1879) - York St South, showing markets & Town Hall (September 1921) [copy date] And let's not forget our friend John Rae, who depicted the scene before the Town Hall was built, when the site was used as a burial gound: - York Street, the Markets, Cathedral and Corporation Offices (1842) - York Street looking south, the Markets, Police Office and temporary Cathedral (1842)

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Golly - enough research there for a thesis!
(That "September 1921" date is way off)

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] I had the same feeling re the 1921 date. Looking closer at the record its revealed as a "Copy of original photograph". So 1921 is the date the photograph was photographed. That's one confusing dating practice.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: 1886 around July/August and at noon. From the Princess Theatre "Hugo's Buffalo Minstrels" (see note). SMH 2/8/1886 p. - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13644403 [They were still performing in 1887 but in various other theatres - with an act like that they had to keep moving ... ]

comment._content: Wow big flies back then! too many horses!
